Topic.Title: TSMC hit record revenues in July

Message.Msg: - "TSMC posted strong revenue results and soaring profits for its 2Q12. The company expects to expand sales revenue by about 7 percent sequentially in 3Q12, which is roughly in line with TSMC's historical average for the third calendar quarter." "We are now seeing a dip in our revenue in the fourth quarter from the third quarter," the Taipei Times quoted Chang as saying. Chang also sees a strong rebound in the second quarter of 2013 after the inventory adjustment." Interesting right? It sure is. TSMC's Chairman Chang just put a great quarter in the books. But unlike current nvidia CEO Jen-Hsun Huang, he is forthright and honest about telling his shareholders that it's Grim Times ahead. -

Message.Title: Despite Nexus 7, Asustek's revenues plunge 16%
Message.Msg: - Oh my! My my my. Maybe that Tegra-powered Nexus 7 tablet is doing too well after all? Asustek's revenue plunged 16.14% in July. http://www.digitimes.com/news/a20120810PD206.html Asustek, Pegatron see sequential drops in July revenues Monica Chen, Taipei; Steve Shen, DIGITIMES [Friday 10 August 2012] Asustek Computer has announced revenues of NT$30.207 billion (US$1.01 billion) for July 2012, declining 16.14% on month and 5.18% on year. Asustek CFO David Chang attributed the decline in July revenues to the pending launch of Windows 8 as consumers are wait for new notebooks as well as new motherboards to hit the market. Sales are expected to remain sluggish in August, Chang noted, adding that the overall sales picture will not become clear until mid-October. However, booming sales of the Nexus 7 tablet PC in the US have helped boost Asustek's brand image as well as its sales in that market, Chang claimed. Meanwhile, EMS provider Pegatron Technology has posted consolidated revenues of NT$63.718 billion for July, slipping 3.2% on month but rising 23% on year. For the first seven months of 2012, revenues amounted to NT$394.764 billion, up 66% on year. Pegatron is conservative about its performance for the third quarter and expects its notebook shipments to drop within 10% sequentially due to weak PC demand in the global market." Sales are expected to remain sluggish in August, boys. According to Chief Chang, the out-of-stock Revenue tracker. -

Topic.Title: wtf Happpened Today...

Message.Msg: Oh dear a little knowledge is a dangerous thing in your very clueless hands. Would you consider 'Jordan Roy-Byrne, CMT (Trendsman) is a Chartered Market Technician, a member of the Market Technicians Association and from 2010-2011 an official contributor to the CME Group, the largest futures exchange in the world. He is the publisher and editor of TheDailyGold Premium. Jordan has 14 years of investing experience.' to be a professional ? http://thedailygold.com/author/admin/ Well listen to him talking about the 300 and 600 day averages affecting Gold and Silver prices ... http://www.kitco.com/ind/Trendsman/jan182012A.html The point you are throughly missing is that any amount of days moving average can be important if you can point to a chart and show it has had a direct influence on price movement, i.e. provided support and/or resistance. Currently Nvidia's chart suck, the 600 (14.69) is above the 200 (14.02) and the 200 is above the 50 (13.02) when you really want that all reversed if you want the stock to fly on minimal volume so that you have golden cross and not death cross conditions. The stock will have to stay above the 600 for enough time to allow the 50 to cross the 200 and the 200 to cross the 600 if you want to see $20+ days again. http://stockcharts.com/c-sc/sc?s=nvda&p=D&yr=1&mn=0&dy=0&i=t48569423554&r=1344512759294

Message.Title: Another tegra 3 phone in china
Message.Msg: http://www.digitimes.com/news/a20120809PD223.html China market: K-Touch rolling out low-priced quad-code smartphone Daniel Shen, Taipei; Steve Shen, DIGITIMES [Friday 10 August 2012] China-based smartphone vendor K-Touch has rolled out a quad-core smartphone, the Hornet II, priced at CNY1,999 (US$314) compared to CNY2,999 of a comparable model, the MX4, launched by fellow vendor Meizu in June. K-Touch's pricing for quad-core models will make it difficult for other vendors to set their prices high when they are trying to step into the quad-core segment in China, said industry sources. The Hornet II comes with a 4.5-inch touchscreen, a 1.5GHz Tegra 3 processor, and an 8-megapixel camera, running on Android 4.0. HTC, Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics have already rolled out quad-core models targeting the high-end segment with prices set higher than US$660, the sources noted. China-based ZTE is scheduled to launch its first quad-core model, the Era, in the third quarter with the price likely to be set below CNY3,000 in order to remain competitive, said the sources. Meanwhile, Huawei will delay the launch of its quad-core model, the Ascend D1 Quad to the fourth quarter. Qualcomm's forthcoming quad-core platform, the S4 Pro APQ8064, will attract more China-based smartphone vendors to venture into the segment, pushing the prices of quad-core models down further, said the sources.

Message.Title: Longs have nothing to lose sleep on (part 2, a repost)
Message.Msg: eir951 wrote: This is a superior company that is being held back from running. I'd love to hear just a thoughtful justification for the action day to day. We should be in the $20s, but my years of observation of this stock have me feeling we'll see $13s again before we see $20. I would defer to your longtime observations on the daily trading quirks of the stock. (To borrow a Briticism, bollocks to those bloody MM stitch-ups, LOL.) Suffice to say the following: 1) The peculiar (some may call it disproportionate) ‘punishment’ of a particular stock is all but unique. For example, fans of tech stocks like MSFT and MRVL would be the first to agree that these stocks are under-appreciated, and lest one forget, they are both dividend-yielding investments no less, at 2.7 and 2.2% respectively. 2) The previous material supply issue (coupled with the earlier Thai floods) that severely crimped the Q2 y/o/y performance comparison, did take the shine off its once stellar price (justifiably so the shorts would say). But with that overcome (hopefully for a good long while) and the timely adjustment/transition to mobile apps almost fully in gear, NVDA is poised to return to its winning ways in sales numbers and in investors' sentiment--the latter of which is really not that hard to be re-cultivated as numbers become increasingly self-evident. I am especially encouraged by the sanguine outlook issuing forth from the CC on Thursday. The corollary: more analyst updates are a matter of course. 3) Expect no precipitous near-term price shoot-up of NVDA; (we missed out on the mo due to some inopportune market events). As usual, any upward trajectory of the price movement would be marked by gyrations of peaks and valleys, and would surely be moderated by the market mood at large. Yesterday’s rather bizarre trading dynamic is but a reminder of the stock’s extreme vulnerability to external factors. I would agree with ibexx’s remark that the odds of a sub-14 price regression are low and be only fleeting at worst. Now, at the risk of sounding presumptuous (and even Pollyannaish), I would call the high at 16.5 before this quarter is out, with the bulk of trading activities snugly straddling the range between 15 and 16 in this time period. Humor me if there are out there those with lenses of the same ilk as mine. Of course, my prognosis is predicated on a shock-free domestic and global economy during this 3rd Q. (Chances of further serious deterioration of the jobless rate at home are less than 50-50 for the next 3 months; then again further woes from Europe and this time from China cannot be discounted.) 4) ibexx88 posted: PLEASE REFRAIN FROM USING STOP LOSS - the MMs would take one look at the order book and drop the bid precipitously and take your stops, before you know it the bid is raised again and your shares are gone. A salient point made. If one has subscription to level 2 quotes, it is of interest to note that NVDA’s stop losses that are set 20 to 30 cents to the prevailing trading price on any day are by and large triggered more than 50% of the time. One would be better off taking profit outright off the table than using ‘protective’ stops with the assumption that it would turn out to be more ‘profitable’ over the long haul. One final observation: Friday was actually a low volume trading day on the Big Board and NASDAQ. Yet for NVDA it was unusually heavy with almost 3X the usual volume and over twice of the day before. But despite the very heavy volume it did little to shave the price at the end of the day. This I read to be a positive development, in effect a consolidating action of the previous day’s 3% gain. GLTA doggone (had to repost under different handle due to an admin glitch

Topic.Title: Despite Nexus 7, Asustek's revenues plunge 16%

Message.Msg: - Geez Best, Everybody and their brother is chopping their future outlook here. Except Jen, of course. He owns entirely too much nvidia stock to be honest. Intel. "But the company also cut its revenue guidance somewhat for the third fiscal quarter, citing a challenging macroeconomic environment." Qualcomm Inc. "But the chip-maker “moderated” its full-year view, lowering the top-end of its forecast for both revenue and adjusted earnings per share." Texas Instruments. "The global economic environment is causing both [customers and distributors] to become increasingly cautious in placing new orders. Our backlog grew last quarter but orders slowed in the month of June and our backlog coverage for September is lower than normal." Advancing Micro Devices. "AMD and other chipmakers are grappling with slowing demand, as consumers shift to mobile devices and economic growth weakens in Europe and emerging markets... reflecting disappointing sales in Europe and China." HTC. "HTC’s struggles did not relent in the second quarter as the company’s profit tumbled 58% compared to the same quarter last year. To make matters worse, the company’s third-quarter guidance sees sales dropping by 23% as margins continue to thin. HTC’s revenue declined at an even swifter rate during the first month of the quarter, and investors reacted on Monday and Tuesday by shaving more than $1 billion from the company’s market capitalization in just two days. “HTC’s weak third- quarter outlook means it will continue to lose market share and any market-share gains in China won’t likely offset its substantial loss in its key Europe and U.S. markets." Asustek Computer Inc. "Asustek CFO David Chang attributed the decline in July revenues to the pending launch of Windows 8 as consumers are wait for new notebooks as well as new motherboards to hit the market. Sales are expected to remain sluggish in August, Chang noted, adding that the overall sales picture will not become clear until mid-October." It's a novel excuse, right? "Consumers are waiting for Windows 8 devices to launch." The best excuse yet came from whoever the company was that said that nobody is buying anything until they see the Genuine Apple iPad 3 and iPhone 5 next month. It could be that Nobody actually knows why their order books are shrinking at an alarming rate, so they just guess at the reason. The Chairman would look silly to tell analysts, "I dunno", right? And then other companies start chopping their orders simply because they see the smarter companies like Intel and Qualcomm, saying that their order books have imploded. And the whole thing snowballs because it's become UNFASHIONABLE to be building electronic devices. Or ordering any parts. Like from nvidia. In the interim, why own any semiconductor stock, right? Probably just dead money for six (6) months or so. Maybe longer. -

Topic.Title: Tangled web of buyout amd rumors

Message.Msg: AMD is dirt cheap ~ $3B - NVDA is ~ $10B and they would have to pay at least $12B - $15B because of the growing and healthy profits. Buy AMD for cheap jointly and have joint patent protection - AMD has tonnes of patents in GPUs and CPUs. NVDA buying AMD would be a huge defocus on a X86 market that's barely growing each year vs ARM mobile growing > +30% a year. X86 performance is Process Technology driven - and there is no way to beat Intel at that - you can have a small advantage but it's blown away as soon as Intel comes out with a new process technology node and they are far ahead in that aspect. The X86 architecture is pretty much mature and relatively rigid - that's why it's impossible for it to compete with ARM on a price performance - process node basis.

Topic.Title: Samsung outs a dual-core ARM Cortex A15 chip with 2560x1600 display support

Message.Msg: - WOW! nvidia gets leap-frogged again! This time by Samsung. Samsung outs a dual-core ARM Cortex A15 chip with 2560x1600 display support Retina display resolution for tablets By Lawrence Latif | Samsung outs a dual-core ARM Cortex A15 chip with 2560x1600 display support Retina display resolution for tablets By Lawrence Latif | Fri Aug 10 2012 16:05 CHIPMAKER Samsung has released the Exynos 5 Dual system-on-chip (SoC) for tablets. Samsung's Exynos SoC processors power a number of high-end smartphones and tablets, however the firm has announced the Exynos 5 Dual will support resolutions higher than Apple's Retina display. The firm said the dual-core chip will support 2560x1600 WQXGA display resolution. Samsung's Exynos 5 Dual is a dual-core 1.7GHz chip that is based on the ARM Cortex A15 architecture. The firm also cited 12.8GB/s bandwidth to two-port 800MHz LPDDR3 RAM but it is the graphics capability of the SoC powered by ARM's Mali T604 architecture that shines, sporting full profile support for OpenCL and OpenGL ES 2.0 as well as 60FPS HD 1080p playback for 3D video. Samsung also touted the Exynos 5 Dual SoC's ability to process 8MP at 30FPS and attach a camera that has zero shutter lag. The firm also said the module's embedded Displayport controller and PHY are integrated into the chip to cut down on power, space and cost. As a graphic illustration of how the desktop monitor market has stagnated, Apple launched the first widely available WQXGA Cinema Display back in 2004 and it has still not been surpassed. Samsung's announcement strongly suggests that next year could see the same 2560x1600 resolution on 7in or 10in displays. For Samsung the Exynos 5 Dual is the first ARM Cortex A15 chip that uses its 32nm High-K metal gate process node. Like most ARM Cortex A15 processors, the Exynos 5 Dual chip is expected to end up in tablets rather than smartphones. µ" Looks like the only left to do with that aging obsolete Tegra line is pull the plug on it, boys. -

Topic.Title: Tangled web of buyout amd rumors

Message.Msg: Last I checked - you need more than a CPU/GPU to make a cell phone or a tablet for starters - Power Management, GPS, NFC, and Wifi. Broadcom when they are ready with their Arm Mobile offerings would be a very serious threat because they have everything under one roof and their RF solutions are probably the most advance and most integrated in the market - perfect for Mobile. The only missing piece is a great Arm CPU/GPU. Nvidia is very weak outside of the CPU/GPU - that's why these two would be a killer combo. QCOM bought Atheros so they can own more of what goes into the CP/Tablets and eventually hope to be a one stop shop.
